title: AB 1850
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 13000 of the Education Code is amended to establish the California Civil Liberties Public Education Act, aimed at educating the public about the exclusion and internment of Japanese Americans. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) was created by Congress in 1980 to review Executive Order 9066's impact on American citizens and recommend remedies. The CWRIC issued reports in 1983 based on 20 days of hearings with over 750 witnesses, including evacuees, government officials, and historians. The federal Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians (CWRIC) concluded that Executive Order 9066 was not justified by military necessity and was driven by race prejudice, war hysteria, and a failure of political leadership. President Ronald Reagan signed the federal Civil Liberties Act of 1988, acknowledging the grave personal injustice done to Japanese-Americans during World War II. The Congress acknowledges the grave injustice done to citizens and permanent residents of Japanese ancestry during World War II, apologizing for the violation of their civil liberties and constitutional rights. The actions were motivated by racial prejudice and wartime hysteria, resulting in significant human suffering. The Education Code is also amended in response to these findings. The Education Code is amended to establish a state test for eligible aliens seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test would assess their understanding of English, history, and government of the United States to meet federal requirements. The Education Code is amended to establish a state test for eligible undocumented foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. This test would assess their understanding of English, history, and government of the United States to meet federal requirements. The Education Code is amended to establish a state test for eligible undocumented foreign nationals seeking permanent residency in California under the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. The Superintendent, in consultation with the Chancellor of the California Community Colleges, will develop or adopt a test to measure English proficiency and knowledge of U.S. history and government. The Governor, Superintendent, Chancellor, Senate President pro Tempore, and Assembly Speaker will petition for approval to use the test as a requirement for federal immigration laws. The Superintendent will distribute a test to educational agencies for eligible foreign nationals applying for legal status under the Federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. Test results will be confidential and only released with written consent for educational purposes. The Superintendent will distribute a test to educational agencies for eligible foreign nationals applying for legal status under the Federal Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. Test results may be transmitted to the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service upon request. School districts and other eligible agencies receiving federal funds must administer the test with appropriate security measures. Section 52613 of the Education Code is amended to require school districts offering classes for nonimmigrant foreign nationals to charge a fee covering the full cost of instruction, with the fee not exceeding the actual cost. The fee must be approved by the governing board at least 90 days before the classes begin. Section 52651 of the Education Code defines key terms for the chapter, including "Board of Governors," "Chancellor," "Community-based organizations," "Department," and "Educational outreach activities." The Department of Education is defined as the State Department of Education. Educational outreach activities include providing information to temporary resident foreign nationals about federal immigration laws and services available to them, as well as educational opportunities for newly legalized persons and other immigrants. The definition of "immigrant" and "newly legalized person" is provided, along with the definition of "services provider" as an organization approved to offer educational services to newly legalized persons. The curr_chunk defines "SLIAG" and "Superintendent" and amends Section 68062 of the Education Code regarding residency rules. It states that a residence is where one stays when not elsewhere for work, cannot be lost until another is gained, and can only be changed by act and intent. Residence can be established independently by a man or woman, with a woman's residence not being dependent on her husband's. The residence can only be changed by act and intent. A woman's residence is not derived from her husband's. The residence of an unmarried minor is where they live with a parent or last lived with a parent. An unmarried minor's residence cannot be changed by their own act or by a legal guardian. A foreign national can establish their residence unless prohibited by federal law. The residence of an unmarried minor foreign national is derived from their parents. Section 68130.5 of the Education Code is amended to exempt certain students from paying nonresident tuition at California State University and California Community Colleges if they meet specific requirements related to high school attendance in California. Section 68130.5 of the Education Code exempts certain students from paying nonresident tuition at California State University and California Community Colleges if they meet specific requirements, including graduation from a California high school or equivalent, enrollment in an accredited institution in California since 2001, and filing an affidavit for lawful immigration status. The Board of Governors and Trustees will establish rules for implementation, and student information is confidential. Student information obtained in the implementation of this section is confidential. Income received as reparation payments for Japanese ancestry interned during World War II shall not be considered in determining financial need. The Superintendent of Public Instruction must certify that certain changes have been made to federal government terminology before certain sections of the act become operative. This includes replacing "alien" with "foreign national" and "illegal alien" with "undocumented foreign national." If the certification is made, Section 2 of the act will become inoperative.
